channel.title: BBC News | News Front Page | World Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Blair hopeful for Mid-East talks
item.description: New Middle East envoy Tony Blair says he is optimistic momentum can be regained in the stalled peace process.

item.title: Poor nations 'need science boost'
item.description: The world's poorest nations are at a technological disadvantage, says a United Nations trade body.

item.title: Mosque survivor 'willing to die'
item.description: A female survivor of Islamabad's Red Mosque siege says she was prepared to die to defend the mosque.

item.title: Calls for Brazil airport to close
item.description: Pressure mounts for Sao Paulo's Congonhas airport to close in the wake of a crash which killed some 200 people.

item.title: No UK 'cash for honours' charges
item.description: The BBC understands that no-one is to face charges after the 16-month cash-for-honours investigation.

item.title: Russia expels four embassy staff
item.description: Four embassy staff are expelled from Moscow in what Britain calls a "completely unjustified" move by Russia.

item.title: US judge dismisses CIA leak case
item.description: A US judge throws out a lawsuit brought by ex-CIA agent Valerie Plame against Vice-President Dick Cheney.

item.title: Italy priest freed in Philippines
item.description: Giancarlo Bossi, the Italian priest abducted last month in the Philippines, has been released.

item.title: Iran shows new scholars' footage
item.description: Iran's TV shows the second part of a programme with two detained US-Iranian scholars held on suspicion of spying.

item.title: JK Rowling rails against spoilers
item.description: JK Rowling hits out at US newspapers that have published plot details from the final Harry Potter book.

item.title: The Open: Garcia takes charge
item.description: Sergio Garcia fires a 65 to lead after day one of the Open Championship.

item.title: Cycling: Hunter powers to victory
item.description: Robbie Hunter takes the 11th stage of the Tour de France in Montpellier.

item.title: First S Leone war crime sentences
item.description: The UN-backed war crimes court for Sierra Leone sentences three rebel leaders to long prison terms.

item.title: Somali talks bombs kill children
item.description: At least five Somali children die in a mortar attack as a reconciliation conference opens.

item.title: Argentina set for campaign launch
item.description: Argentina's First Lady, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, is set to launch her campaign for October's presidential poll.

item.title: Black gets bail before sentencing
item.description: Disgraced media tycoon Conrad Black is told he can remain free on bail until his sentencing in November.

item.title: North Korea talks set no deadline
item.description: North Korea nuclear talks agree on goals for the next phase of disarmament but no deadline.

item.title: Power cut fears after Japan quake
item.description: Japan fears power shortages, as the scale of earthquake damage to a nuclear power plant becomes clear.

item.title: EU gender pay gap 'no narrower'
item.description: Europe has made little progress towards equal pay for men and women, the European Commission says.

item.title: Ukraine toxic smoke hits 140
item.description: The number of people being treated for symptoms blamed on a toxic cloud in Ukraine doubles in a day to 140.

item.title: Battles continue at Lebanon camp
item.description: The Lebanese army continues its bombardment of Islamist militants cornered in a Palestinian refugee camp.

item.title: Egypt police move to Gaza border
item.description: Egypt sends police to its border with Gaza to stop Palestinians stranded in Sinai from crossing over.

item.title: Scores killed in Pakistan attacks
item.description: More than 40 people are killed in three separate bomb attacks in Pakistan, say officials.

item.title: Nepalese 'goddess' is reinstated
item.description: A girl of 10 is reinstated as a living goddess in Nepal after a controversy over her visiting the US.

item.title: Labour holds on to Blair's seat
item.description: Labour keeps Tony Blair's old seat in the by-election prompted by his resignation - but with a reduced majority.

item.title: Fed fears $100bn credit losses
item.description: Federal Reserve boss Ben Bernanke warns the crisis in the US sub-prime lending market may cost $100bn.

item.title: Alcohol law 'trebles' A&E visits
item.description: New 24-hour drinking may have trebled alcohol-related admissions to inner city A&E departments, researchers say.

item.title: Farm bird decline 'can be halted'
item.description: Farmers who provide "bed and breakfast" for wild birds could help reverse the decline in farmland species, experts say.

item.title: Fast food brands hit kids online
item.description: Despite rules banning the advertising of unhealthy food online, some brands bend the rules, research suggests.

item.title: Emmys recognise Sopranos swansong
item.description: America's top TV awards lavish nominations on the last series of hit mob drama The Sopranos.

item.title: The Green Room
item.description: Chemical engineering, not carbon offsetting, is needed to deliver a low carbon future.
